That's not a good idea, Python 2 is really deprecated: https://www.python.org/doc/sunset-python-2/
> We are volunteers who make and take care of the Python programming language. We have decided that January 1, 2020, was the day that we sunset Python 2. That means that we will not improve it anymore after that day, even if someone finds a security problem in it. You should upgrade to Python 3 as soon as you can.

1613761105_1PZivKEBF8sdpTRbeb9Wug8HMv3Cf.body:
I want to address this statement:
> The market is still small, and 21 million bitcoins is very few for the population of Earth.

Every bitcoin consists of 1E8 (100 mil) satoshis so it's actually 2100000000000000 (21E14) indivisible units. Equals to 300000 satoshis per person currently. Even if that isn't enough for practical purposes (if one satoshi becomes much more that $1 for example) nothing stops the developers from allowing to spend a fraction of satoshi. Just like in a normal transaction there would be an additional field that specifies these fractions in the transaction output and the software checks if the balances are correct (as it already does for regular satoshis/bitcoins).

Say, million satocents per 1 satoshi should be enough. It's a pure technicality. In the end all that changes is the way of calculating your balance, you'll have normal satoshis + these "satocents" (probably displayed as a fractional part) just like you have dollars and cents today. Instead of predictable inflation like in DOGE/Monero Bitcoin still stays deflationary while not sacrificing the usability.

Yeah, it's a quote from xealits. Also, regarding the distribution skepsis: I don't think it matters much nor that fair distribution can be achieved in principle. There will always be early adopters who believed in something new and 95% of the population would just shrug and move along. Later the early adopters are either rewarded (if the thing takes off) or punished (by losing their investments). No one knows it beforehand, it's a risk that you can take. The Bitcoin whitepaper and all its source code was public from the beginning (if you don't count those first blocks that Satoshi mined himself).

Nothing prevented people from joining and getting their share, except their ignorance or lack of knowledge. But how would they learn about it if not through the media? And media wasn't interested because it was just another "geek toy". There's no one to blame but yourself if you haven't taken time to read the paper and understand how revolutionary this thing is. Best part is that the whitepaper is written in extremely simple language with close to no math so any IT person should be able to understand the core principles, unlike the modern complex Proof of Stake algorithms. I don't understand how PoS works, I'll be honest. It's a lot of math and probabilities and I'm bad in understanding math even though I'm a programmer, mostly because of crazy notation that's different in every paper and one-letter-variables-in-100-different-fonts. But I understood Bitcoin instantly after reading those few pages. It's brilliant in its simplicity.

That part above was about the impossibility of fair distribution, tl;dr you can't convince 100% of humanity to adopt your new shiny thing so that it's fair and everyone is rich in 10 years. Not possible. And it doesn't matter because of that.

Another point is why it doesn't matter. To understand that let's think why this uneven distribution might matter.

- all coins are hoarded, it's impossible for an average Joe to buy some
- the price can be easily manipulated by the whales
- it's unfair, some people have a lot of money and I don't!

Even people who hold a lot of BTC currently need to move them to make them valuable. There's no point in sitting on your coins if you can't get anything tangible for them. Sooner or later you will spend them (sell or exchange for goods&services). So there will be no shortage of coins. Miners will also sell them to pay for their new hardware and associated costs. And traders as usual will provide liquidity to scalp a little bit for themselves. Traders are _good_ for you even though it might look like they profit off you (which is also true).

The price indeed can fluctuate quite a lot, we've seen some ups and downs. But Bitcoin supply is limited so by all means its price will go up in the long run. If it goes down it's just an opportunity for everyone to buy more. Also, many big funds and companies invested in BTC and I personally don't think they will dump it to oblivion just for the sake of it. So buy the dips carefully and it might pay off in a year or two!

The unfairness point is already deboonked twice, it's your fault you haven't adopted earlier but you can still do it because BTC is divisible and you can buy a small fraction for even $100 or so. Just keep your coins in your own local wallet and not at exchanges. Not your keys — not your coins.

1614726531_14JFttTvjwR9PitBWPMU8FEqRCwAC.body: Such a shame ZN is written in Python... a very unfortunate language choice these days (I know it started years ago when it was reasonable). It can't be integrated into anything, can't be compiled or installed on a slower device (like ARM/MIPS/STM controller), it can't utilize more than one core and often consumes 100% of it for a while and everything else gets stuck (not even the sidebar can be loaded) etc. There were attempts to rewrite it in Go but all those projects are long abandoned. IPFS isn't good currently, that I agree with. But ZN isn't progressing much either. It's a good and working tech but the implementation is fundamentally flawed and needs a complete rewrite to work reliably on mobile and low power devices without a huge slow runtime with an ugly GIL in the middle.

1615551849_1BzSytFDUwQ6UJCdJxsf9QjNdeVq4.body: You have many hardcoded links that point to http://127.0.0.1:43110. Not everyone hosts the node on the same machine, for example I have mine installed on a NAS so your images don't load for me. Best way to link to the same host is to use links in the format of `/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/merged-CDN/15fDN4wasXuyS8krtKvrxEVmWWLz6Qh518/data/users/18ASnnFHznjoSDUR9b8UdBrz2p3RjzoeuG/obscura1615552163679.jpg` so no matter what the host is it should work.

> [5h1n1n9d4rkn355](#comment_8_1BzSytFDUwQ6UJCdJxsf9QjNdeVq4jt5WX): What is an NAS?

Network Attached Storage but it's unrelated. It's my another PC so I use its IP instead of 127.0.0.1 and I don't run ZeroNet locally. Also, your images most likely won't work if someone opens your site using a public gateway.

1618002997_1HV7aMJLo3XMuij1h17kP12ZYvp1Y.body:
> [karhen](#comment_24_1PSE9tMzYJFEAAXYArxwJj56F9x23TqpS2): I guess freenet encrypts even your data ? (unknown is always encrypted) [...]

Freenet works in a different way fundamentally. It stores, sends and receives encrypted blocks and the key to decrypt them isn't stored or transferred anywhere. It's included in the link instead. So you retrieve a block using the hash part of the link and then decrypt it locally using the key part of the URL. This way no one knows what they store and there's no way to find it except via getting the hashes and keys to decrypt those blocks. ZN only uses hashes like torrents and no detached keys, this whole idea isn't applicable by design. You can encrypt your local storage but it's very different: if you give away the key/password to decrypt it it will be obvious which sites you explicitly visited and seeded. Freenet has plausible deniability, ZN doesn't.

1620567834_173pXRMqj6vLLVMV92FuyxAJWmcD5.body:
Try Lightning Network. It's truly a game changer, instant transactions with Bitcoins (faster than credit card processing), tor-grade anonymity (no blockchain traces at all), almost non-existent fees (~1-2 sats per transaction which is currently about $0.00055). At the low level it requires some non-obvious setup like acquiring inbound capacity to receive Bitcoins but:
1) if you only want to spend, that doesn't concern you at all, open a channel and start spending
2) you can use mobile wallets like Breez or Muun, they handle all that for you (they open a channel _to_ you automatically so you get the capacity transparently), those look pretty decent and minimalistic. Basically, on mobile you don't care about these details at all, you press Send or Receive and that's it. Everything else is done behind the scenes and you're always in control of your money.

I was surprised to find out that LN is actually quite popular and supported by many merchants, there are various apps for both spending and receiving money using it. I heard about it long ago but there was no significant buzz, recently I decided to check it out and it's very alive and kicking! Still, it's in beta so don't lock all your savings there.

PS: LN is not another shitcoin/fork and greedy handrubbers behind it. It works with Bitcoin and Litecoin currently and it needs the actual blockchain to function. But it's used for initial deposit and final settlement only, all actual transactions happen outside in its own network, again, using the native crypto (BTC or LTC) and not some stupid token substitute.

1623652167_1ByyvGdKSdKTywR6F8tmFAk3RsWUH.body: You should _really_ replace your local IP with 127.0.0.1. No need to expose your internal network addresses to the world (also they don't work for anyone except yourself).

> [croatame](#comment_28_19RaaMJeGXcJzLxeKXWH9pynfjgmm33VZS): There's no need to include that when making a link. Put the / and the long string of characters and the trailing / within the parenthesis and that link will work for everyone equally. [...]

Yes, but it doesn't work like that on every zite. Some automatically replace whatever IP the user posts with just / (so it's relative to the current domain/ip and works for everyone). Some replace it with 127.0.0.1:43110 and it breaks for people hosting the node on a remote machine. Some do nothing. The best way is the first method, of course.
